metadata.title: Optimizing Starbucks App Offers. Leveraging machine learning to create… | by Luisa | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Besides being the largest coffeehouse company in the world, Starbucks is notoriously known for its rewards program. They added a record 1.4 million customers to their member base earlier this year…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: largest coffeehouse company in the world

all_paragraphs: Besides being the largest coffeehouse company in the world, Starbucks is notoriously known for its rewards program. They added a record 1.4 million customers to their member base earlier this year, ending the quarter with 18.9 million active members across the U.S., which marks a 16% year-over-year growth. With the introduction of its technology initiative, Deep Brew, Starbucks is constantly ideating and working on a suite of AI tools to elevate every aspect of their business.

So what exactly is Starbucks doing right? What could be implemented to maximize earnings? These are some questions I sought to better understand that will be explored in this blog. By answering these questions, Starbucks can target customers that are more likely to redeem offers, which would reduce promotional costs and maximize offer earnings. Successfully targeting offers towards appropriate users also leads to an enhanced, personalized experience, which in turn could improve customer retention.

In this post, we will analyze simulated data that mimics real customer purchases on the Starbucks rewards app. Transaction, demographic, and offer data will be explored to reveal consumer behavior trends. These trends will then be used to build a machine learning model that predicts offer success. The objective is to send promotions to users that are more likely to respond and to only send them offers that have a high probability of being redeemed.

The Starbucks datasets provided by Udacity contain demographic, offer, and transaction data from the Starbucks rewards mobile app. The same datasets can be found here on Kaggle. Feel free to download these and follow along!

Starbucks sends out an offer to users every few days through their mobile app. These offers can be an advertisement, discount, or a buy one get one free (BOGO) promotion. Not all users receive the same promotions and offer frequency varies per user. The data is contained in three files with the following schemas:
portfolio.json — contains offer ids and meta data about each offer (duration, type, etc.)
profile.json — demographic data for each customer
transcript.json — records for transactions, offers received, offers viewed, and offers completed
Several challenges are presented in this data:
Given the limitations of the datasets, cleaning and data preprocessing will be crucial in revealing consumer behavior trends and building a predictive model.
Our analysis will follow this outline:

Let’s begin by assessing the portfolio dataset. In our initial observations of this DataFrame, we can see that ‘channels’ can be separated into separate columns for better analysis. We can also rename the ‘id’ column to ‘offer_id.’
The clean dataset should look like this:

Moving on to the profile dataset, we see again that the ‘id’ column can be clearer by renaming it to ‘customer_id.’ Gender can also be converted to numerics or can be separated into columns. The ‘became_member_on’ should be in a readable date format. While 118 is a possible profile age, we can see that this value is an outlier when plotting the distribution. There are no ages between 101 and 118. Based on the distribution, and this age gap, we can infer that this is user input error and replace this value with NaN. We can also drop rows with missing age, gender, and income data.
The cleaned profile DataFrame should look like this:

For the transcript data, we can rename the ‘person’ column to ‘customer_id.’ The ‘value’ column can be separated into columns for offer_id and amount. The ‘event’ column can also be split into columns by offer type and transaction. Since we have a ‘customer_id’ column in the cleaned profile DataFrame, we can drop the transcript customer id’s that are absent in the profile dataset.
The cleaned transcript dataset should look like this:
For the next section, we want to explore all variables so let’s merge these DataFrames. When looking at the offer id, we can see that there are 10 types of offers:

Here we can see the 10 different offer ids and their associated offer types. Let’s rename these to: ‘bogo_1’, ‘bogo_2’, ‘discount_1’, ‘info_1’ etc. Finally, let’s merge the cleaned datasets. The merged DataFrame should have these qualities:

Now for the fun part, let’s check out some trends. When looking at the shape and time column in the merged DataFrame, we can tell that the experiment was run for 30 days and 272,388 events were collected.

So far, we’ve looked at the offers sent to users during this 30 day period. Let’s build a DataFrame that can be used to analyze customer behavior by aggregating transaction, offer, and demographics data.
The resulting merged_cust DataFrame should have these qualities:
From here, we can use the customer DataFrame to plot the following variables:
Our exploratory findings revealed demographic spending trends and offer types. Let’s pull customer behavior by offer from the customer DataFrame and complete these steps:
In our initial assessment of the merged DataFrame, we identified 10 different offer IDs. Let’s see how they rank in terms of earnings by following these steps:
The printed results reveal the following ranking of offers:
We can evaluate each offer’s percent success by defining a function that aggregates completed offers by ID. Let’s go ahead and write this function.
Now we can plot percent success by offer type. Let’s also plot the offer type count to see if there’s any association between count and success rate.

We will now use the customer spending trends identified in our analyses to build a model that predicts whether a user will respond to an offer. The process of sending promotions to users requires labor and is a cost to the organization. If Starbucks implements a prediction model, they can alleviate these resources, while ensuring that promotions are being sent to customers that historically interact with offers and that only offers with a high percent success are being sent to them. The increased number of redeemed offers and reduced use of internal resources will maximize Starbucks’ earnings.

While the initial cleaning was sufficient for our analysis, the data needs to be transformed into a useful and efficient format for training. We will also remove features that are not relevant for our model. The preprocessing steps for each dataset are outlined below:
The final DataFrame should look like this:
Split into train and test datasets
Now let’s split the data into train and test datasets and ensure the model doesn’t overfit the data by evaluating the test data performance metrics.

The naive classifier assumes that all offers are successful and serves as a base model. We can use the naive predictor performance to compare the machine learning algorithms we will build. Let’s see the performance metrics:
The naive classifier suggests a 64% chance of a successful offer.

Logistic regression models construct a linear decision boundary to separate successful and unsuccessful offers. Let’s construct this model using liblinear clf as an estimator in RandomizedSearchCV to fit the training data.
Now let’s define the model performance evaluation function:
Model performance evaluation suggest that the logistic regression model’s accuracy and f1-score is better than the naive predictor.

The logistic regression model constructed a linear decision boundary, separating successful and unsuccessful offers. However, the exploratory analysis of user demographics and offer types suggests a non-linear decision boundary. For this reason the ensemble methods, random forest and gradient boosting, will be built and tested next.

Random forest uses multiple decision trees and trains each tree independently, using a random sample of the data. Let’s build a random forest model that uses n_estimators, max_features, max_depth, min_samples_split, and min_samples_leaf as tuning parameters and RandomizedSearchCV for fitting:
Results suggest that the random forest model’s accuracy and f1-score is better than the naive predictor

Feature importance refers to a numerical value that describes a feature’s contribution to building a model that maximizes its evaluation metric. Random forest classifier is a model that estimates feature importance during training. Let’s retrieve the relevant importance scores for each input feature using the algorithm for feature importance implemented in scikit-learn:
Now let’s plot the estimated feature importance based on random forest:
The customer offer effectiveness training data suggests that the top five features based on their importance are:
We can use this feature importance ranking to improve our predictive model by selecting features with top scores and removing features with the lowest scores.

Gradient boosting builds trees one at a time, where each new tree helps correct errors made by the previously trained tree. Let’s build this model using random grid and parameters of loss, learning_rate, n_estimators, min_samples_leaf, and min_samples_split to tune and fit using RandomizedSearchCV:
Results suggest that a gradient boosting model’s accuracy and F1-score is better than the naive predictor
Results suggest that the gradient boosting model has the best accuracy and random forest model has the best f1-score.

In an ideal scenario, the best model should have the highest accuracy and f1-score. Since this isn’t the case, let’s evaluate the two performance metrics to determine the best model for tuning and refinement:

Since the user data in this analysis is not symmetric, the f1-score will be used to determine the best model. Given the best f1-score, the random forest model will be used as the best model for the remainder of this analysis. This model also makes the most sense since the random forest typically results in very high quality models that are fast to train. Random forest can handle a large amount of training data efficiently and inherently so it is well suited for future use with multi-class problems given big data from Starbucks’ 18.9 million active users.
Let’s tune our random forest model by first building a DataFrame that ranks all models by performance. From this dataset, let’s print the model’s best hyperparameters.
With this information, we can refine our model using the ‘best’ hyperparameters:
Let’s see the refined random forest model’s hyperparameters:
Lastly, we should evaluate test data performance to ensure that the random forest model data did not overfit the training data:
The test data accuracy of 0.695 and f1-score of 0.797 suggests that the random forest model constructed did not overfit the training data.

Customer spending is greater with increasing age and income. It might be worth exploring whether Starbucks should increase the frequency of promotions based on age and salary. Since females spend more than all other genders, it would also be interesting to explore the reasoning behind these higher numbers.

Since the top three features are associated with customer offers, the model could be improved by creating features that describe an offer’s success rate as a function of offer duration, difficulty, and reward. The addition of these features should construct a better decision boundary, separating successful and unsuccessful customer offers, returning a model with more reliable performance metrics.

There’s a reason why companies like Starbucks are focused on building world-class AI and ML capabilities. In this particular case, machine learning models used to distribute personalized promotions increases the odds of offer conversion and reduces the cost of labor, which in turn maximizes profits. Starbucks’ implementation of AI increasingly powers their personalization engine, optimizes store labor allocations, and drives inventory management. Starbucks is constantly implementing changes as seen in their most recent loyalty program update, which offers more ways to pay and earn rewards, making it easier for customers to get their next free cup of coffee.

Whether you’re a loyal Starbucks consumer or a coffee aficionado unable to fathom the PSL’s 17-year position within the zeitgeist, consider what prompted you to purchase from the coffee giant during your next visit.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Data analyst with a curiosity for revealing patterns and solving business problems
